The update here and integrity_algo.cpp because CI will report the following error after switching to meson:

```
==1090==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on address 0x60300002a448 at pc 0x555d4cf2f007 bp 0x7fff09b5d000 sp 0x7fff09b5cff0
READ of size 1 at 0x60300002a448 thread T0
    #0 0x555d4cf2f006 in bool std::equal<__gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<unsigned char*, std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > >, __gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<unsigned char const*, std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > >, bool (*)(unsigned char, unsigned char)>(__gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<unsigned char*, std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > >, __gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<unsigned char*, std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > >, __gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<unsigned char const*, std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > >, bool (*)(unsigned char, unsigned char)) /usr/include/c++/11/bits/stl_algobase.h:1586
    #1 0x555d4cf2c3a9 in cipher::integrity::AlgoSHA1::verifyIntegrityData(std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > const&, unsigned long, __gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<unsigned char const*, std::vector<unsigned char, std::allocator<unsigned char> > >) const ../integrity_algo.cpp:61
    #2 0x555d4ceec395 in IntegrityAlgo_HMAC_SHA1_96_VerifyIntegrityDataFail_Test::TestBody() ../test/cipher.cpp:170
```
Done
Ah, you did the autotools removal here.
Done

Why did this need to get added for Meson?

...

I see the issue in the test file, but I still don't understand what this change does and why.  The lambda here _should_ be the _default_ comparison already.

> Why did this need to get added for Meson?
> 
> ...
> 
> I see the issue in the test file, but I still don't understand what this change does and why.  The lambda here _should_ be the _default_ comparison already.

I am not sure, I used the following and UT passed:
https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/equal
```
template< class InputIt1, class InputIt2 >
constexpr bool equal( InputIt1 first1, InputIt1 last1,
                      InputIt2 first2, InputIt2 last2 );
                      
(since C++20)
```

I still don't understand.  I don't think adding the end iterator should do anything different.  If it does, it likely means we're truncating somewhere incorrectly and now the integrity comparison is comparing against truncated data.

Either way, I think the first1, last1, first2, last2 overload is the safest, because if they are different lengths, we won't run past on either side. In theory, they should always be the same length, but this is the safe, explicit route.
The maintainers can decide what to do here.  It looks odd to me but Vernon seems to think it is better.
Why is there 'required: false' on all of these?  Aren't these hard dependencies?

> Why is there 'required: false' on all of these?  Aren't these hard dependencies?

Yes, I agree with you
But @gokulsvg has different opinions
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-net-ipmid/+/55087/1/meson.build#27

@gokulsvg, what do you think?

@gokulsvg, please respond.  I don't know why you made this recommendation.  We do not add them anywhere else in any other projects.  All adding `required: false` does is give really bad compile failure messages instead of nice "you are missing libfoo" from meson.
I agree, these are all required, and should not be marked as optional.

> I agree, these are all required, and should not be marked as optional.

I agree, removed all required.

> Couldn't this pattern been refactored to be this?
> 
>     auto integrityIter = packet.insert(...);
>     
> This fix probably belongs in a separate commit because it looks to be fixing a valid bug.

sure, I will push a new patch for this issue
Ack
I would prefer that these changes go in a separate commit from the one that is adding the meson buid.
Done
